audio_caption: The clip begins with electronic music playing in the background. The music is rhythmic, with synthesizer-like sounds creating a sense of tension or urgency. A man begins speaking, discussing the role of defense contractors in the surveillance state, mentioning specific corporations and people. The music continues softly underneath the speech.

The audio clip begins with male speech, discussing RAND Corporation and its role in national security, noting it was "one of the very few nonprofit private corporations" working for this establishment. The speaker then references other organizations, noting they were "much closer associated" than RAND. Throughout the speech, there is consistent ambient noise suggesting a public outdoor setting. The speaker concludes, followed by a cut-off.

The audio begins with a male speaker mentioning "Booz Allen" as one of many corporations that handle sensitive data, noting that "70% of the intelligence budget goes to private contractors". He questions why he, as a "mid-level analyst" at Booz Allen, has access to information that invades privacy and is unavailable to Congress. Throughout the speech, there is consistent background ambiance with indistinct sounds, creating an environment.

The audio clip features a male speaker with a slightly exasperated tone discussing issues of access to classified information. He cites an experience of having access to a "7,000-page top secret study" that a senator couldn't get, and expresses his opinion that private contractors having such access is absurd and "smells of fascism." He also criticizes the blurred lines between corporations and the government. His tone is critical throughout. Background sounds of light wind rustling and the ambience of an outdoor environment are noticeable during the speech, adding a sense of realism to the recording.

The audio clip features a male speaker inquiring about the government not paying for court reporters in the Bradley Manning case. He states that funds were raised, and asks the interviewee how this was possible. The interviewee, also male, clarifies that they had to raise money for their own copy of the transcript, as copying cost a lot. Throughout the speech, there is noticeable ambient background noise.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing a court case where the judge didn't provide a transcript, holding the trial "as closely as possible, as a closed trial." He mentions the Freedom of the Press Foundation crowdfunding money to hire a reporter with court capabilities to provide a transcript. This was needed, he says, as otherwise, they would rely on the scribbled notes of a few reporters. The speaker's tone is informative. The background sounds contain indiscernible ambient noise.

The clip starts with a male speaker questioning, "On one hand, the government does not have the resources to monitor our federal court system", then skeptically inquires, "You're saying we have the resources to monitor every single communication across all the innocent civilians?". The speaker's tone appears inquisitive and somewhat challenging. A second male speaker then responds in a measured tone, stating it's "a matter of priorities" that "applies right across the board to human-". The clip abruptly ends mid-sentence.

The audio clip features one male speaker with a critical and somewhat sarcastic tone. He discusses how "the government" seems to prioritize spending on things like "attack submarines" and "ABM systems" instead of infrastructure or healthcare. Interwoven with this speech is subtle, ambient background noise suggesting an outdoor public area.

The audio begins with a male speaker posing a question about Snowden and Bradley Manning, asking what advice the interviewee has for those working at the NSA or as defense contractors who witness injustice, considering their past experiences. A female speaker then starts to give her answer. Simultaneously, background ambiance is present, marked by medium-level vehicle noise.

An adult male is speaking in an instructional tone, advising listeners to avoid his past mistakes, such as "go to Congress first" or "go to my superiors in the Defense Department." He suggests following the advice of others, to avoid being seen as "troublemakers and potential leakers" and facing retaliation. The speaker references NSA personnel who made similar errors. He notes that they "did it wrong."

The audio clip opens with a male speaker asserting "Snowden did it right," continuing to elaborate on how to follow Snowden's example in handling sensitive information, cautioning against trusting government informants and advocating for maintaining anonymity. The speaker emphasizes, "do it like Snowden," praising his approach. The speaker's tone is instructional and somewhat emphatic. His voice is overlaid with a moderate level of ambient noise, suggesting a public or outdoor environment.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing Edward Snowden's actions, mentioning mistakes like choosing Hong Kong and Russia, and suggesting Venezuela or Ecuador as alternatives. The speaker has a conversational tone. The background contains ambient noise, possibly indicating an outdoor setting.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker posing a question regarding the millennial generation, mentioning "Daniel Ellsberg, Snowden, Zimmerman", and asking "why should they care?". This question is delivered in an inquisitive tone. The clip is predominantly speech-based.

The clip begins with speech from a single male speaker, who states, "Not because there is any guarantee that telling the truth will bring about change," followed by a summary of someone's fear that nothing would change, while also mentioning a chance for change and the high stakes involved. He continues, emphasizing that humanity and democracy are on the line. All the while, ambient background sounds of a city street are present.

The clip begins with a male speaker, discussing Snowden's revelations about global interference with citizens' privacy, noting that the US has far greater capabilities, but other countries are catching up. His tone is serious and somewhat resigned, suggesting the difficulty of changing this reality. He reflects on the new world order and the uncertainty of altering it. His words are followed by silence.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the importance of truth and taking risks, while being careful not to endanger others. His tone is thoughtful. He suggests that those who know the truth is being concealed should speak out in a way that attracts attention and protects them from retaliation. He concludes with a thank you, acknowledging the speaker's lifetime of activism. The clip ends.

The audio clip begins with speech, where a male speaker says, "It's a great pleasure and honor to see you." He is followed by a different male speaker replying, "Thank you." There is speech in the background as well.
